THE NEWS..LETTER
VOL. XVI, NO. 13.

BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 22, 1912.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

STUDENTS WANT THE SAY

SOUTHERN I. A. TO BE FORMED

CROWDS GREET DR. NITOBE

HARLAN IS THE COACH

Many Communications Received by The
News-Letter Urging that the Undergraduates Help Decide Upon
the Four-Year Rule.

Principal Colleges of South to Meet in
Track and Field Championships.
England to Represent Hopkins.

Lectures in McCoy Hall on Japan Are
Well Attended—No Likelihood
of War Between Nations.

Famous Princeton Athlete Has Been Selected to Train Both Baseball and
Football Teams at the Johns
Hopkins University.

For the purpose of defermininc,
the time, place and rules for holding the proposed Southern Intercollegiate track and field championships, representatives of nearly
all the leading Southern colleges
will meet in Washington on Saturday, February 3.
Mr. Joseph T. England has been
appointed by the Hopkins Athletic
Board to represent the interests
of the J. H. U. at this meeting.
Mr. England was one of the originators of the idea of forming a
Southern intercollegiate association
for the purpose of holding annual
track and field championships, and
the progress which has been made
towards such an organization is
largely due to the energetic way in
which he has worked ,up enthusiasm for the plan among the various
Southern universities and colleges.
It was first planned for representatives of Hopkins, the University of Virginia, the University
of North Carolina, and Georgetown
to get together and organize. It
was thought that as soon as something definite had been done, some
of the other institutions would
apply for membership. The plan
has interested other institutions
from the start, and three of them
have already asked for the privilege of being represented at the
meeting on February 3. They are
Washington and Lee University,
the Agricultural and Mechanical
College of North Carolina, and the
Virginia Polytechnic Institute.
Mr. England said that, owing to
the large number of institutions
which will be represented in the
championships, four places will
probably count in every event.
This means that every track team
should try to develop enough good
athletes to enter at least four men
in every event. From present indications the number of contestants
will be so large that preliminaries
will be required the day before the
championships to determine the
athletes who are entitled to compete in the finals.

Dr. Inazo Nitobe, president of
the First National College and professor in the Imperial University
of Tokio, gave on Monday and
Thursday last the second and
third of his lectures on Japan. At
both lectures McCoy Hall was
filled, people even standing up in
the rear of the room. Dr. Nitobe
holds -the complete attention of
his audiences, not only because of
the clear and scholarly presentation of his subject, but also because
of his witty and clever observations.
The Monday lecture was concerning the "Geographical Features
of Japan." The speaker dwelt
mainly on the influence of Japan's
island position; that the natural
boundaries restraining the Japanese had only worked to their advantage in unity, freedom from
foreign invasion and foreign complications; where China and Korea
had suffered, Japan had escaped.
"Japan," he said, "is aware that
her mission is to mediate between
the old and the new civilizations.
On the Asiatic continent there .are
crude manifestations of impatience
of European control; of fear and
hatred of the White Peril.
"For all these recent signs of a
hostile attitude that the Far East
takes toward the West, Japan is held
directly or indirectly responsible.
She is in the exceedingly delicate
and unenviable position—scapegoat
for the whole of Asia. He reads these
signs of the times amiss who sees
bloody conflicts as their final and
inevitable issues. As in a few years
the waters of the Atlatitic will
mingle with the waters of the
Pacific; the civilization born on the
shores of the Mediterranean and
brought to maturity by the denizens of the Atlantic Coast will
soon enrich the venerable civilization of the Orient."
Dr. Nitobe evidently thinks that
there is little chance of war between
this country .and Japan, for in
Thursday's lecture on "History,"
after tracing the' development of
Japan for twenty centuries back,
he showed that the United States
had always been a friend of Japan,
and tha Japan in nowise intended to forget our friendship.

The editorial in last week's issue
of THE NEws-LETTER, although it
made no appeal for support, has
caused widespread comment and
commendation among those interested in Hopkins athletics. Below
We print a few of the letters which
. we have received from students and
alumni who believe that the final
authority should rest with the student body. The authors of these letters are both opponents and advocates of the so-called four-year rule.
Not one expression of distrust
of the Athletic Board has .been received, but all agree that the matter
IS the most important one which we
have had to decide for some years
... so important, in fact, that a meeting of the alumni has been called
for tomorrow evening at the Hopkins Club.
The writers point out that the
students could not be adequately
represented by their class members
on the Board, and so the initiative
or referendum should be resorted
to. The weight of opinion favors
.the referendum; that is, the subMission of a specific plan by the Athletic Board to the students for ratification, rejection or amendment.
Some of the letters follow:
January 17, 1912.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
It certainly seems to me that the
undergraduates, who are the most
affected, should be given an opportunity to vote on the four-year rule
restriction. For my part, I am as
Yet "on the fence," and I think that
Is the way with a number of my
Class mates. We do not think, however, that we can be adequately
represented by the man we elected
from the class to fill a place on the
Board, and so we want to have a
say. I think that the best plan
Would be for the Board to submit a
Specific proposal,and then let us vote
on it. We could be educated sufficiently to cast intelligent ballots,
through the publication of arguments, pro and con, in the columns
of THE NEWS-LETTER, and through
Speeches made at the meeting.
NON-PARTISAN.

January 20, 1912.

Eddie Harlan, who made a great
reputation as a football and baseball star at Princeton University,
was signed Wednesday night to
coach the 'Varsity nine and eleven
for one season. As announced in
Tiii NEWS-LETTER several weeks
ago, he had been definitely determined upon, and the only hitch was
a disagreement as to some of the
details, but these were successfully
done away with and the contract
signed on Wednesday by Graduate
Al onager Holmes and Mr. Harlan.
Both on the gridiron and the
diamond, Harlan is an all around
player, but better still, he has had
coaching experience of the best
kind, and this is why Hopkins is
fortunate to get him. His work at
the Gilman Country School was excellent and he also helped out in
getting the Princeton eleven into
shape to play some of its big games.
Locally he is well known by his
playing on the Maryland Athletic
Club Baseball team.
Now that Harlan has signed the
papers he will start in immediately
with the candidates for the Black
and Blue baseball team. There is
some pretty good material waiting
for him and work will begin in the
cage about the first of next month.
In the meantime, however, the
coach will talk over things with
Captain Pieper. An ambitious schedule has been arranged for the nine
and such teams as Yale, Princeton,
Harvard and Pennsylvania will be
seen on the Homewood diamond.
Harlan is a quiet young man, but
he has the knowledge. If he is permitted to use his own judgment and
work out things in his own way he
will place Hopkins on the athletic
map.
To accept the position at Hopkins, Harlan turned down two of.
fers with larger figures in the salary
column. A Southern 'varsity wanted him badly as head football coach
and Princeton wanted him to return. But Harlan is a lawyer now
and he wants to remain in Baltimore to practice his profession, so
lie cut down the salary to a figure,
he believed Hopkins could pay.
At first Hopkins did not want to
pay as much as Harlan asked, but
\yanted Harlan badly, so the men
who have the welfare of the 'Varsity
at heart dug deeply into their pockets and made up the difference.
From many points Harlan is a
great baseball coach. He played the
outfiejd for Princeton and was a

streak on the bases. After he came
to Baltimore, Mickey Whitehurst,
than whom there is no better allaround coach in these parts, turned
Harlan into a pitcher. During the
years he has been with the Maryland Athletic Club—and he will be
with it again this season—he has

On the football gridiron Harlan

and is just as clever at quarter as

always had stood him in great stead
in every sport he has taken up.
With such a ,capable man in touch
with its students the whole year,
Hopkins should find Harlan the
most valuable athletic asset it ever
possessed.

THE NEWS—LETTER, JANUARY 22, 1912.
THANKS FOR THE BOUQUET
One Kind Friend
and Well-Wisher Sticks
by Us in a Manner Which Is as
Rare as It Is Noble.

January 16, 1912. s
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
Stick to your guns! Treat everybody fairly, but don't take all the
criticisms you receive too seriously.
I don't believe
you do, but it must
be a little discouraging to print
letters like two in the last number.
Here's an antidote for you:
First—The undergraduates like
THE NEWS-LETTER as it is now run
and want to see it keep on in the
same general way. They read it
and enjoy it; and, just between you
and me, with all due respect to Mr.
Kuehn's opinion, they get the
biggest part of their enjoyment out
of the little personalties and nearwitticisms that have livened its
columns this year for the first time.
Keep plenty of current in the
Wires, and don't mind the sparks.
If you can get the services of Mr.
Wegg and H. L. Mencken you will
improve the paper still more.
Secondly—THE NEWS-LETTER is
Prospering for the first time in
years. I don't believe this is due
to the editorial policy any more
than to other causes—notably, to
the activities of the most energetic
manager any undergraduate enterPrise at Hopkins ever had—but,
hear in mind, that prosperity and
editorial enterprise came hand in
hand. The paper deserved better
success this year; and, behold! it
met with it. Don't dare to go
back to the dry-as-dust period if
You value the continued opulence
of the journalistic exchequer.
Thirdly—In my judgment, the
Paper has promoted good feeling
by its new jocular jottings. Perhaps there were mistakes, but they
Were unimportant when compared
With the real service the editorial

policy has rendered by injecting a
little picturesque and piquant coloring into the dull intellectual routine. A classmate of mine nearly
broke up the grinding session in
the far end of the library the other
day by a fit of uproarious laughter
over a little classroom joke on himself that an enterprising reporter
had preserved in THE NEwsLETTER. He had to show it to
everybody in the room, and it
seemed to me that he was better
rewarded for his faithful subscription to the paper ever since
he entered the University by the
amusement he got from that little
incident than by all the serious
reading matter previous editors had
thrust upon him.
I shan't undertake to argue the
larger questions of college journalism with Mr. Kuehn and the clan
for which he is spokesman. I
merely venture to say to "X" that
if I am not mistaken in my judgment of the Hopkins undergraduate body—and I trust that I am not
—they would be so far from protesting at the Chicago Maroon's "accepting literally" Slosson's statement about the local habit of dimepitching that they would laugh
heartily with our Standard Oil
friends at the joke on themselves,
even as did my classmate, and get
back at the Maroon next week.
Oh, for the pen of a Chesterton
to analyze and immortalize the
Philosophy of Kidding! Lacking
which, let me commend to Mr.
Kuehn and all others the little
essay on "The American Undergraduate" in the current Century;
and in especial some few paragraphs dealing with fellowship between student and professor and
a certain extremely disrespectful
"faculty song." Can it be that the
conception of a more desirable relationship between the faculty and
the undergraduate body than Mr.
Kuehn's "well-deserved respect"
finds it so difficult to gain a footing in an atmosphere permeated
with the traditions of Hopkins
dignity? If such be the case, then
ho, for the purer air of Homewood!
But the cry of "back to the
kindergarten !" is already ringing
in my ears. Frivolity I confess,
and lay claim to no higher rank
than that of undergraduate; but,
being an undergraduate, I take
pride in signing myself a dignified
SENIOR.

ALUMNI COUNCIL VACANCIES

A. B.

Douglas H. Gordon, A. B. '87, BaltiFive Members Are to Be Elected This
Year, Two to the Ph. D. Group.
The List of Nominations.

The following letter has been
sent to all alumni:
BALTIMORE, Jan. 10, 1912.
DEAR SIR—There are five members to be elected to the Alumni
Council of the Johns Hopkins University this year, four under the
rule that four vacancies, one in each
class, must occur each year, and
one by reason of the fact that Dr.
Charles P. Neill, United States
Commissioner of Labor, a representative in the Council of the Ph.'
D. group, has resigned. Thus, in
the Ph. D. group, there are two
vacancies to be filled. The names
of the four retiring members are
starred among the candidates hereby placed before you. They are
eligible for re-election, with the proviso that at least one new man must
be elected each year. Of the candidates to be elected this year, two
must hold the degree of Ph. D.,
one that of M. D., one that of A.
B., and one may be "At large,"
i. e., may be one holding any degree, including proficients in electricity and fellows who have received no degree. All such degrees
or such fellowships must have been
held for at least ten years prior to
the date of nomination.
On February 1, ballots are to be
sent to all alumni and to students
who have been in good standing in
the University for two years, but
have not received a degree, who
must sign and return them to the
secretary of the Alumni Association not later than February is.
On that date the ballots will be
counted by a committee of three
appointed by the president of the
Alumni Association and the chairman of the Alumni Council, and the
result will be announced on February 22, 1912, and the newly-elected officers will assume office the
.•
following May.
The nominees are as follows:

be given the final say on the fouryear rule question. One of the
main arguments used by those in
favor of the eligibility regulation
is that the undergraduates would
profit. Certainly, then, the undergraduates should be permitted to
accept or reject the proffered benefit.
The constitution of the Athletic
Association, according to our interpretation, makes no provision for
the calling of a mass-meeting by
petition. That the students want
to make the final decision is shown
by the deluge of letters which we
have received. We feel sure that
President Fulton will yield to this
popular demand.

THE NEWS-LETTER, JANUARY 22, 1912.

DEBATE SUBJECT UNDETERMINED

Editorial Overflow.
Reserved Seats at the Lectures.

THE NEWS-LETTER has received
several communications suggesting
that the University authorities provide a sufficient number of reserved
seats at the Nitobe lectures so that
the students who, on account of being detained in laboratories or
classes, are unable to arrive before
5 o'clock will be able to get good
Places. Instead of publishing these
letters, which, in substance, are
Practically the ame, we take this
method of calling attention .to the
lack of reserved facilities.
The only lecture course in recent years which was so well attended as the one now being given
by Dr. Nitobe, was that by Dr.
Ernest Flagg Henderson on "The
French Revolution." On account
of the great crowds, Dr. Henderson gave the last lectures in the
concert hall of the Academy of
Music, and there ample reserved
seats were provided, with attendants to see that only those entitled
to admission got the privilege.
In McCoy Hall, at the present
time, the first two or three rows
have on the chairs pieces of card.bohrd marked "Reserved," but this
is no bar to those who want to sit
down, and at the three lectures,
which have so far been given, people
Who have no connection with Hopkins have occupied some of the
choicest places, with the result that
tudents have been forced to crowd
into any available corner. Three
rows would be ample, if interlopers
Were kept out, and, although the
Public is cordially invited to hear
1)r. Nitobe speak, the attendance
of students is so great and so unusual that every effort should be
made to encourage it.

Thursday, January 25.

The question for the HopkinsNew York debate has been tentatively agreed upon by Dr. French
and Professor Palmer of the College of the City of New York.
Some phase of the following subject will be discussed :" That corporations doing business in interstate commerce should be brought
under the control of the Federal
Government." The limitation and
wording of this question are still to
be worked out.
It is of interest that almost
identically the same problem will
be debated by the triangular league
composed of Cornell, Columbia and
the University of Pennsylvania.
The question as phrased in these
debates, however, will also contain
the provision that the Sherman law
be repealed as a preliminary to
more direct regulation of the corporations.
Manager. Getz has submitted a
tentative agreement to the New
York authorities embodying the
usual provisions for the holding of
the contest here and in that city.
The date is still undetermined, but
it is thought there will be no difficulty in finding one that will suit
both sides. The New York Evening,
Post recently contained a very substantial account of the proposed
debates, commenting upon the fact
that such a unique and satisfactory
arrangement for a dual contest had
been agreed upon.
The interclass debate will be upon
the same question as the later one,
and both the, date and the complete
form .of the subject for it are in
suspense until the conclusion of the
arrangements with New York.

If Mary Garden wore more clothes,
And Russian dancers ran to hose,
If La Follette would never more

Appear with hair served pompadour,
If Carnegie refused to give
Advice on how young men should live,
If Theodore gave "I" the snub
And shelved the Ananias Club,
If Taft once frowned, and left behind
That talk of the "judicial mind,"
If Bryan had no word to say
But let his party go its way,
If weather men were sometimes right,
And street cars seldom filled at night,
If those six books that sells the best
Were not more junklike than the rest,
If Edison and Burbank quit
Announcing some new wondrous hit,
If in the chat about The Game
One never visioned Ty Cobb's name.
If cables never creaked and sagged
'Neath Kipling's verse, and no one
flagged
Doc Wiley for a pure food theme,
How unfamiliar would life seem!

Marriage is a tie, especially for
the man who is roped in.

THE NEWS—LETTER, JANUARY 22, 1912.
THE NEWS-LETTER'S MAIL BAG
A Column in Which the Correspondents
Are Allowed Latitude, but Shoulder the Responsibility.

(THE NEWS-LETTER is always glad to
Publish letters of reasonable length upon
topics of interest in University circles.
Alumni especially are urged to make use
of this column. All communications, as
evidence of good faith, should be endorsed with the name of the writer,
Which, upon request, will be withheld.)

January 12, 1912.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

One of the faults of Johns Hopkins is that there is no system of
letting the student body as a whole
know what is happening and what
is going to happen. Of course, we
have the bulletin boards and THE
NEws7LETTER, which do the work
to a certain- extent. But no student,
Who is doubtful of his ability, is
going to push himself forward into
ally activity without some kind of
'personal invitation. I do not mean
that it is necessary for the leaders
of the various activities to see each
man in. the University personally,
and ask him to try out, but I do
mean that there should be some
stronger invitation than a mere
newspaper article., or a bulletinWard notice. I do not see why it
IS not practical for us to have a
Weekly assembly of the entire student body. At this meeting all the
announcements for the week could
be made, and talks could be given
Which would keep the students informed about and interested in
everything that is going on around
school. Perhaps it would be hard
to get the men out, but other
schools have made success of it, so
Why can't we? If there is any spirit
at all here, and there certainly is a
little, this, in my opinion, is the
best means to get it to working.
X—X.
January 16, 1912.

To the

Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

May I have a small space in your
columns to speak of a very large
Subject?
At a number of colleges and
universities, including Columbia,
Ilarvard, Princeton and Yale,
chapters of the Intercollegiate
Socialist Society have been formed
With the stated object: "To pro/note an intelligent interest in Socialism among college men and
Women."
It is only reasonable to look for
t he .Hopkins, as a "university," to
°e numbered among the progressives.
Several Hopkins men have already signified their interest in
this movement.
The undersigned will be glad to
hear directly from all who approve,
or who wish further information
upon the plan to start a Hopkins
chapter.
Very respectfully,
REV. JAS. L. S/AILEY, A.. B.'91.
Antapolis, Md.

ANNUAL TRACK AND YIELD MEET

A BUSINESS SCHOOL
Of Exceptional Merit

Sophomore and Freshman Classes Are
Working Hard—Regulation
Events of A. A. U.

.\ 1 anager Brown of the 'Varsity
team has set Saturday afternoon,
February 3, for the annual track
and field meet between the sophomore and freshman classes. It will
take place in the cage. The seating capacity is limited, so that
tickets will be issued for places in
the gallery. The gymnasium, however, will be thrown open to accommodate the crowd.
The candidates for both teams
are working hard, along with the
'Varsity squad. The freshmen
have some men out who show
promise of making a good team.
Captain Uhler seems to be the best
in the distance event, together with
Biser and Deems. Prince and
Mason will enter the shorter races.
The strong part of the team seems
to be found in the field events, with
these men entered: De Witt, Short,
Masbn, Schwartz, Voshell, Tarr
and Thompson.
The sophomore team will consist
of what is left of last year's aggregation. Schreiber, who won the
shot-put, has left; Bryan and Reilly
are also gone. Liebensperger bids
fair to take Schreiber's place in the
shot-put. He is putting the weight
very nearly forty feet, and doing
well in the high jump and polevault. Wells, who is captain, will
offset the rest of the lost strength.
Last year he was sick at the time
of the meet. He will be the principal contestant in the quarter mile
and the mile. Catlin will enter the
half, and run the mile with Wells.
Hollyday, Snyder, Del Valle, Chenoweth .and Sutton will complete the
team.
The contest will consist of the
regulation events of the A. A. U.,
so far as the size of the cage
admits: 30 and 44o yard dashes,

January 20, 1912.
To the Editor of THE

NEWS-LETTER:

I am an alumnus, and, as such,
expect to attend the meeting next
week. Our function, however, is
to advise, not to decide; to talk, not
to act. The real power lies with
the students, and I therefore want

ALUMNUS, '07.
January 20, 1912.
The suggestion that recently appeared in your columns that the
question of a four-year rule in athletics be submitted to the student
body for decision is excellent. The
students ought to have the final say
in all matters as important as this;
and the way in which they have
disposed of problems of the same
sort in the past promises a wise
and deliberate action in this case.
Alumni may advise and athletic
boards execute, but the students
themselves should decide.
T. BROOKE PRICE.

THE NEWS..LETTER
VOL. XVI, NO. 13.

BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 22, 1912.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

STUDENTS WANT THE SAY

SOUTHERN I. A. TO BE FORMED

CROWDS GREET DR. NITOBE

HARLAN IS THE COACH

Many Communications Received by The
News-Letter Urging that the Undergraduates Help Decide Upon
the Four-Year Rule.

Principal Colleges of South to Meet in
Track and Field Championships.
England to Represent Hopkins.

Lectures in McCoy Hall on Japan Are
Well Attended—No Likelihood
of War Between Nations.

Famous Princeton Athlete Has Been Selected to Train Both Baseball and
Football Teams at the Johns
Hopkins University.

For the purpose of defermininc,
the time, place and rules for holding the proposed Southern Intercollegiate track and field championships, representatives of nearly
all the leading Southern colleges
will meet in Washington on Saturday, February 3.
Mr. Joseph T. England has been
appointed by the Hopkins Athletic
Board to represent the interests
of the J. H. U. at this meeting.
Mr. England was one of the originators of the idea of forming a
Southern intercollegiate association
for the purpose of holding annual
track and field championships, and
the progress which has been made
towards such an organization is
largely due to the energetic way in
which he has worked ,up enthusiasm for the plan among the various
Southern universities and colleges.
It was first planned for representatives of Hopkins, the University of Virginia, the University
of North Carolina, and Georgetown
to get together and organize. It
was thought that as soon as something definite had been done, some
of the other institutions would
apply for membership. The plan
has interested other institutions
from the start, and three of them
have already asked for the privilege of being represented at the
meeting on February 3. They are
Washington and Lee University,
the Agricultural and Mechanical
College of North Carolina, and the
Virginia Polytechnic Institute.
Mr. England said that, owing to
the large number of institutions
which will be represented in the
championships, four places will
probably count in every event.
This means that every track team
should try to develop enough good
athletes to enter at least four men
in every event. From present indications the number of contestants
will be so large that preliminaries
will be required the day before the
championships to determine the
athletes who are entitled to compete in the finals.

Dr. Inazo Nitobe, president of
the First National College and professor in the Imperial University
of Tokio, gave on Monday and
Thursday last the second and
third of his lectures on Japan. At
both lectures McCoy Hall was
filled, people even standing up in
the rear of the room. Dr. Nitobe
holds -the complete attention of
his audiences, not only because of
the clear and scholarly presentation of his subject, but also because
of his witty and clever observations.
The Monday lecture was concerning the "Geographical Features
of Japan." The speaker dwelt
mainly on the influence of Japan's
island position; that the natural
boundaries restraining the Japanese had only worked to their advantage in unity, freedom from
foreign invasion and foreign complications; where China and Korea
had suffered, Japan had escaped.
"Japan," he said, "is aware that
her mission is to mediate between
the old and the new civilizations.
On the Asiatic continent there .are
crude manifestations of impatience
of European control; of fear and
hatred of the White Peril.
"For all these recent signs of a
hostile attitude that the Far East
takes toward the West, Japan is held
directly or indirectly responsible.
She is in the exceedingly delicate
and unenviable position—scapegoat
for the whole of Asia. He reads these
signs of the times amiss who sees
bloody conflicts as their final and
inevitable issues. As in a few years
the waters of the Atlatitic will
mingle with the waters of the
Pacific; the civilization born on the
shores of the Mediterranean and
brought to maturity by the denizens of the Atlantic Coast will
soon enrich the venerable civilization of the Orient."
Dr. Nitobe evidently thinks that
there is little chance of war between
this country .and Japan, for in
Thursday's lecture on "History,"
after tracing the' development of
Japan for twenty centuries back,
he showed that the United States
had always been a friend of Japan,
and tha Japan in nowise intended to forget our friendship.

The editorial in last week's issue
of THE NEws-LETTER, although it
made no appeal for support, has
caused widespread comment and
commendation among those interested in Hopkins athletics. Below
We print a few of the letters which
. we have received from students and
alumni who believe that the final
authority should rest with the student body. The authors of these letters are both opponents and advocates of the so-called four-year rule.
Not one expression of distrust
of the Athletic Board has .been received, but all agree that the matter
IS the most important one which we
have had to decide for some years
... so important, in fact, that a meeting of the alumni has been called
for tomorrow evening at the Hopkins Club.
The writers point out that the
students could not be adequately
represented by their class members
on the Board, and so the initiative
or referendum should be resorted
to. The weight of opinion favors
.the referendum; that is, the subMission of a specific plan by the Athletic Board to the students for ratification, rejection or amendment.
Some of the letters follow:
January 17, 1912.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
It certainly seems to me that the
undergraduates, who are the most
affected, should be given an opportunity to vote on the four-year rule
restriction. For my part, I am as
Yet "on the fence," and I think that
Is the way with a number of my
Class mates. We do not think, however, that we can be adequately
represented by the man we elected
from the class to fill a place on the
Board, and so we want to have a
say. I think that the best plan
Would be for the Board to submit a
Specific proposal,and then let us vote
on it. We could be educated sufficiently to cast intelligent ballots,
through the publication of arguments, pro and con, in the columns
of THE NEWS-LETTER, and through
Speeches made at the meeting.
NON-PARTISAN.

January 20, 1912.
To the Editor of THE NEws-LErrER:
It seems to me that the present
agitation concerning a four-year
rule in Hopkins athletics should be
settled by a meeting of the Athletic Association, or, in other words,
by the students themselves. The
matter certainly concerns the stu(Continued on page 8 col. 3.)

Eddie Harlan, who made a great
reputation as a football and baseball star at Princeton University,
was signed Wednesday night to
coach the 'Varsity nine and eleven
for one season. As announced in
Tiii NEWS-LETTER several weeks
ago, he had been definitely determined upon, and the only hitch was
a disagreement as to some of the
details, but these were successfully
done away with and the contract
signed on Wednesday by Graduate
Al onager Holmes and Mr. Harlan.
Both on the gridiron and the
diamond, Harlan is an all around
player, but better still, he has had
coaching experience of the best
kind, and this is why Hopkins is
fortunate to get him. His work at
the Gilman Country School was excellent and he also helped out in
getting the Princeton eleven into
shape to play some of its big games.
Locally he is well known by his
playing on the Maryland Athletic
Club Baseball team.
Now that Harlan has signed the
papers he will start in immediately
with the candidates for the Black
and Blue baseball team. There is
some pretty good material waiting
for him and work will begin in the
cage about the first of next month.
In the meantime, however, the
coach will talk over things with
Captain Pieper. An ambitious schedule has been arranged for the nine
and such teams as Yale, Princeton,
Harvard and Pennsylvania will be
seen on the Homewood diamond.
Harlan is a quiet young man, but
he has the knowledge. If he is permitted to use his own judgment and
work out things in his own way he
will place Hopkins on the athletic
map.
To accept the position at Hopkins, Harlan turned down two of.
fers with larger figures in the salary
column. A Southern 'varsity wanted him badly as head football coach
and Princeton wanted him to return. But Harlan is a lawyer now
and he wants to remain in Baltimore to practice his profession, so
lie cut down the salary to a figure,
he believed Hopkins could pay.
At first Hopkins did not want to
pay as much as Harlan asked, but
\yanted Harlan badly, so the men
who have the welfare of the 'Varsity
at heart dug deeply into their pockets and made up the difference.
From many points Harlan is a
great baseball coach. He played the
outfiejd for Princeton and was a

January 16, 1912. s
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
Stick to your guns! Treat everybody fairly, but don't take all the
criticisms you receive too seriously.
I don't believe
you do, but it must
be a little discouraging to print
letters like two in the last number.
Here's an antidote for you:
First—The undergraduates like
THE NEWS-LETTER as it is now run
and want to see it keep on in the
same general way. They read it
and enjoy it; and, just between you
and me, with all due respect to Mr.
Kuehn's opinion, they get the
biggest part of their enjoyment out
of the little personalties and nearwitticisms that have livened its
columns this year for the first time.
Keep plenty of current in the
Wires, and don't mind the sparks.
If you can get the services of Mr.
Wegg and H. L. Mencken you will
improve the paper still more.
Secondly—THE NEWS-LETTER is
Prospering for the first time in
years. I don't believe this is due
to the editorial policy any more
than to other causes—notably, to
the activities of the most energetic
manager any undergraduate enterPrise at Hopkins ever had—but,
hear in mind, that prosperity and
editorial enterprise came hand in
hand. The paper deserved better
success this year; and, behold! it
met with it. Don't dare to go
back to the dry-as-dust period if
You value the continued opulence
of the journalistic exchequer.
Thirdly—In my judgment, the
Paper has promoted good feeling
by its new jocular jottings. Perhaps there were mistakes, but they
Were unimportant when compared
With the real service the editorial

policy has rendered by injecting a
little picturesque and piquant coloring into the dull intellectual routine. A classmate of mine nearly
broke up the grinding session in
the far end of the library the other
day by a fit of uproarious laughter
over a little classroom joke on himself that an enterprising reporter
had preserved in THE NEwsLETTER. He had to show it to
everybody in the room, and it
seemed to me that he was better
rewarded for his faithful subscription to the paper ever since
he entered the University by the
amusement he got from that little
incident than by all the serious
reading matter previous editors had
thrust upon him.
I shan't undertake to argue the
larger questions of college journalism with Mr. Kuehn and the clan
for which he is spokesman. I
merely venture to say to "X" that
if I am not mistaken in my judgment of the Hopkins undergraduate body—and I trust that I am not
—they would be so far from protesting at the Chicago Maroon's "accepting literally" Slosson's statement about the local habit of dimepitching that they would laugh
heartily with our Standard Oil
friends at the joke on themselves,
even as did my classmate, and get
back at the Maroon next week.
Oh, for the pen of a Chesterton
to analyze and immortalize the
Philosophy of Kidding! Lacking
which, let me commend to Mr.
Kuehn and all others the little
essay on "The American Undergraduate" in the current Century;
and in especial some few paragraphs dealing with fellowship between student and professor and
a certain extremely disrespectful
"faculty song." Can it be that the
conception of a more desirable relationship between the faculty and
the undergraduate body than Mr.
Kuehn's "well-deserved respect"
finds it so difficult to gain a footing in an atmosphere permeated
with the traditions of Hopkins
dignity? If such be the case, then
ho, for the purer air of Homewood!
But the cry of "back to the
kindergarten !" is already ringing
in my ears. Frivolity I confess,
and lay claim to no higher rank
than that of undergraduate; but,
being an undergraduate, I take
pride in signing myself a dignified
SENIOR.

The following letter has been
sent to all alumni:
BALTIMORE, Jan. 10, 1912.
DEAR SIR—There are five members to be elected to the Alumni
Council of the Johns Hopkins University this year, four under the
rule that four vacancies, one in each
class, must occur each year, and
one by reason of the fact that Dr.
Charles P. Neill, United States
Commissioner of Labor, a representative in the Council of the Ph.'
D. group, has resigned. Thus, in
the Ph. D. group, there are two
vacancies to be filled. The names
of the four retiring members are
starred among the candidates hereby placed before you. They are
eligible for re-election, with the proviso that at least one new man must
be elected each year. Of the candidates to be elected this year, two
must hold the degree of Ph. D.,
one that of M. D., one that of A.
B., and one may be "At large,"
i. e., may be one holding any degree, including proficients in electricity and fellows who have received no degree. All such degrees
or such fellowships must have been
held for at least ten years prior to
the date of nomination.
On February 1, ballots are to be
sent to all alumni and to students
who have been in good standing in
the University for two years, but
have not received a degree, who
must sign and return them to the
secretary of the Alumni Association not later than February is.
On that date the ballots will be
counted by a committee of three
appointed by the president of the
Alumni Association and the chairman of the Alumni Council, and the
result will be announced on February 22, 1912, and the newly-elected officers will assume office the
.•
following May.

Let the Students Decide.

Again we request that the students
be given the final say on the fouryear rule question. One of the
main arguments used by those in
favor of the eligibility regulation
is that the undergraduates would
profit. Certainly, then, the undergraduates should be permitted to
accept or reject the proffered benefit.
The constitution of the Athletic
Association, according to our interpretation, makes no provision for
the calling of a mass-meeting by
petition. That the students want
to make the final decision is shown
by the deluge of letters which we
have received. We feel sure that
President Fulton will yield to this
popular demand.

Comedy or Ignorance?

Richard Harding Davis, the
writer, who was a student here
back in the eighties, bad a story
of college life in the Saturday
Evening Post last week. It was a
good story, but Mr. Davis unfortu'lately selected "Gilman" as the
name of the college professor who
figures as the unconscious hero,
and then said that he did as much
for his college as "Dr. Osler did
for Johns Hopkins or as Walter
Camp does for Yale." Was it
ignorance or a desire to be jocular
which made the author compare
the work of Walter Camp to that
ot Dr. Osler ? And why give the
revered name of "Gilman" to a
fresh-water college professor of
history, who, by the indefatigable
efforts of a press agent, is made to
appear a great historian?

THE NEWS-LETTER, JANUARY 22, 1912.

DEBATE SUBJECT UNDETERMINED

Editorial Overflow.
Reserved Seats at the Lectures.

THE NEWS-LETTER has received
several communications suggesting
that the University authorities provide a sufficient number of reserved
seats at the Nitobe lectures so that
the students who, on account of being detained in laboratories or
classes, are unable to arrive before
5 o'clock will be able to get good
Places. Instead of publishing these
letters, which, in substance, are
Practically the ame, we take this
method of calling attention .to the
lack of reserved facilities.
The only lecture course in recent years which was so well attended as the one now being given
by Dr. Nitobe, was that by Dr.
Ernest Flagg Henderson on "The
French Revolution." On account
of the great crowds, Dr. Henderson gave the last lectures in the
concert hall of the Academy of
Music, and there ample reserved
seats were provided, with attendants to see that only those entitled
to admission got the privilege.
In McCoy Hall, at the present
time, the first two or three rows
have on the chairs pieces of card.bohrd marked "Reserved," but this
is no bar to those who want to sit
down, and at the three lectures,
which have so far been given, people
Who have no connection with Hopkins have occupied some of the
choicest places, with the result that
tudents have been forced to crowd
into any available corner. Three
rows would be ample, if interlopers
Were kept out, and, although the
Public is cordially invited to hear
1)r. Nitobe speak, the attendance
of students is so great and so unusual that every effort should be
made to encourage it.

Thursday, January 25.

The question for the HopkinsNew York debate has been tentatively agreed upon by Dr. French
and Professor Palmer of the College of the City of New York.
Some phase of the following subject will be discussed :" That corporations doing business in interstate commerce should be brought
under the control of the Federal
Government." The limitation and
wording of this question are still to
be worked out.
It is of interest that almost
identically the same problem will
be debated by the triangular league
composed of Cornell, Columbia and
the University of Pennsylvania.
The question as phrased in these
debates, however, will also contain
the provision that the Sherman law
be repealed as a preliminary to
more direct regulation of the corporations.
Manager. Getz has submitted a
tentative agreement to the New
York authorities embodying the
usual provisions for the holding of
the contest here and in that city.
The date is still undetermined, but
it is thought there will be no difficulty in finding one that will suit
both sides. The New York Evening,
Post recently contained a very substantial account of the proposed
debates, commenting upon the fact
that such a unique and satisfactory
arrangement for a dual contest had
been agreed upon.
The interclass debate will be upon
the same question as the later one,
and both the, date and the complete
form .of the subject for it are in
suspense until the conclusion of the
arrangements with New York.

If Mary Garden wore more clothes,
And Russian dancers ran to hose,
If La Follette would never more

Appear with hair served pompadour,
If Carnegie refused to give
Advice on how young men should live,
If Theodore gave "I" the snub
And shelved the Ananias Club,
If Taft once frowned, and left behind
That talk of the "judicial mind,"
If Bryan had no word to say
But let his party go its way,
If weather men were sometimes right,
And street cars seldom filled at night,
If those six books that sells the best
Were not more junklike than the rest,
If Edison and Burbank quit
Announcing some new wondrous hit,
If in the chat about The Game
One never visioned Ty Cobb's name.
If cables never creaked and sagged
'Neath Kipling's verse, and no one
flagged
Doc Wiley for a pure food theme,
How unfamiliar would life seem!

Marriage is a tie, especially for
the man who is roped in.

THE NEWS—LETTER, JANUARY 22, 1912.
THE NEWS-LETTER'S MAIL BAG
A Column in Which the Correspondents
Are Allowed Latitude, but Shoulder the Responsibility.

(THE NEWS-LETTER is always glad to
Publish letters of reasonable length upon
topics of interest in University circles.
Alumni especially are urged to make use
of this column. All communications, as
evidence of good faith, should be endorsed with the name of the writer,
Which, upon request, will be withheld.)

January 12, 1912.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

One of the faults of Johns Hopkins is that there is no system of
letting the student body as a whole
know what is happening and what
is going to happen. Of course, we
have the bulletin boards and THE
NEws7LETTER, which do the work
to a certain- extent. But no student,
Who is doubtful of his ability, is
going to push himself forward into
ally activity without some kind of
'personal invitation. I do not mean
that it is necessary for the leaders
of the various activities to see each
man in. the University personally,
and ask him to try out, but I do
mean that there should be some
stronger invitation than a mere
newspaper article., or a bulletinWard notice. I do not see why it
IS not practical for us to have a
Weekly assembly of the entire student body. At this meeting all the
announcements for the week could
be made, and talks could be given
Which would keep the students informed about and interested in
everything that is going on around
school. Perhaps it would be hard
to get the men out, but other
schools have made success of it, so
Why can't we? If there is any spirit
at all here, and there certainly is a
little, this, in my opinion, is the
best means to get it to working.
X—X.
January 16, 1912.

To the

Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

May I have a small space in your
columns to speak of a very large
Subject?
At a number of colleges and
universities, including Columbia,
Ilarvard, Princeton and Yale,
chapters of the Intercollegiate
Socialist Society have been formed
With the stated object: "To pro/note an intelligent interest in Socialism among college men and
Women."
It is only reasonable to look for
t he .Hopkins, as a "university," to
°e numbered among the progressives.
Several Hopkins men have already signified their interest in
this movement.
The undersigned will be glad to
hear directly from all who approve,
or who wish further information
upon the plan to start a Hopkins
chapter.
Very respectfully,
REV. JAS. L. S/AILEY, A.. B.'91.
Antapolis, Md.

ANNUAL TRACK AND YIELD MEET

A BUSINESS SCHOOL
Of Exceptional Merit

Sophomore and Freshman Classes Are
Working Hard—Regulation
Events of A. A. U.

.\ 1 anager Brown of the 'Varsity
team has set Saturday afternoon,
February 3, for the annual track
and field meet between the sophomore and freshman classes. It will
take place in the cage. The seating capacity is limited, so that
tickets will be issued for places in
the gallery. The gymnasium, however, will be thrown open to accommodate the crowd.
The candidates for both teams
are working hard, along with the
'Varsity squad. The freshmen
have some men out who show
promise of making a good team.
Captain Uhler seems to be the best
in the distance event, together with
Biser and Deems. Prince and
Mason will enter the shorter races.
The strong part of the team seems
to be found in the field events, with
these men entered: De Witt, Short,
Masbn, Schwartz, Voshell, Tarr
and Thompson.
The sophomore team will consist
of what is left of last year's aggregation. Schreiber, who won the
shot-put, has left; Bryan and Reilly
are also gone. Liebensperger bids
fair to take Schreiber's place in the
shot-put. He is putting the weight
very nearly forty feet, and doing
well in the high jump and polevault. Wells, who is captain, will
offset the rest of the lost strength.
Last year he was sick at the time
of the meet. He will be the principal contestant in the quarter mile
and the mile. Catlin will enter the
half, and run the mile with Wells.
Hollyday, Snyder, Del Valle, Chenoweth .and Sutton will complete the
team.
The contest will consist of the
regulation events of the A. A. U.,
so far as the size of the cage
admits: 30 and 44o yard dashes,
half mile, mile, 12-lap relay race
(1,2oo yards) for four men, high
jump, broad jump, shot-put and
pole-vault.

the question.
January 20, 1912.
To the Editor of THE

NEWS-LETTER:

I am an alumnus, and, as such,
expect to attend the meeting next
week. Our function, however, is
to advise, not to decide; to talk, not
to act. The real power lies with
the students, and I therefore want
to commend your editorial urging
a mass-meeting, and hope that your
request will be granted.
ALUMNUS, '07.
January 20, 1912.
The suggestion that recently appeared in your columns that the
question of a four-year rule in athletics be submitted to the student
body for decision is excellent. The
students ought to have the final say
in all matters as important as this;
and the way in which they have
disposed of problems of the same
sort in the past promises a wise
and deliberate action in this case.
Alumni may advise and athletic
boards execute, but the students
themselves should decide.
T. BROOKE PRICE.
